info.game_comments: First game of Season 8. First game with new set.

(1, 1).clue: These flat-bottomed boats were specially designed to travel down early canals

(2, 1).clue: The Norse goddess Freya had the unusual habit of weeping tears of this precious metal

(3, 1).clue: Henry VIII's court for this racquet sport is still used at Hampton Court Palace

(4, 1).clue: His nickname was a contraction of "satchel mouth"

(5, 1).clue: In the phrase "prep school", prep is an abbreviation for this

(6, 1).clue: Baked oysters are sometimes served on a bed of the "rock" type of this seasoning

(1, 2).clue: In case you have to leave the oasis in a hurry, this is the faster of the 2 types of camel

(2, 2).clue: The name of this netherworld river is Greek for "hateful"

(3, 2).clue: Squaw Valley, Calif. & Lake Placid, N.Y. are the 2 U.S. sites that have hosted these games

(4, 2).clue: Part of his name appears in the titles of his albums "Milestones" & "Miles Ahead"

(5, 2).clue: Ralph Waldo Emerson wrote, "Men are what" these relatives "made them"

(6, 2).clue: Spring-operated tongs are often used to hold the shells of these garden gastropods

(1, 3).clue: The Academic  American Ency. calls this vehicle the main means of transportation in China

(2, 3).clue: Stargazers should know these 7 sisters are the daughters of Pleione, an ocean nymph

(3, 3).clue: This former heavyweight boxing champ's last bout was a 1981 loss to Trevor Berbick

(4, 3).clue: It's the title of Billie Holiday's autobiography & the Diana Ross film about her

(5, 3).clue: In the folklore of this religion, Dybbuks are evil spirits who can take possession of the living

(6, 3).clue: Cocktail sausages wrapped in dough & baked are called "pigs in" these

(1, 4).clue: This company apologized after it found out the cars stomped by a monster truck in its TV ad were altered

(2, 4).clue: In some accounts, these goat-men are the sons of Hermes & a naiad

(3, 4).clue: This New York Knicks center was NBA rookie of the year for 1985-86

(4, 4).clue: This bandleader's theme song was "Take the 'A' Train"

(5, 4).clue: Mr. Wizard said his all-time favorite experiment is getting one of these into a milk bottle

(6, 4).clue: Chimichangas are often topped with this avocado mixture

(1, 5).clue: Add one more of these to a catamaran & you have a trimaran

(2, 5).clue: This Greek sea god was sometimes called "Earth-shaker"

(4, 5).clue: He recorded "Fathers & Sons" with his father Ellis & brother Branford

(5, 5).clue: Appropriately, it's the national rose of Syria

(6, 5).clue: Some people serve the Liptauer type of this with beer, other prefer it with white wine

(1, 1).clue: This king married Germaine de Foix, niece of Louis XII, after the death of Isabella

(2, 1).clue: Jackie Collins wrote "The World is Full of Divorced Women" & "The World is Full of" these "Men"

(3, 1).clue: It's Italian for a "master" conductor or composer

(4, 1).clue: An agnostic is waiting for proof of this one way or the other before taking sides

(5, 1).clue: Joe, the prizefighter hero of "Golden Boy", has this "Napoleonic" last name

(6, 1).clue: This Maine city is the closest major U.S. harbor to Europe

(1, 2).clue: In the 1890s this great French actress bought a Paris theatre & renamed it for herself

(2, 2).clue: In "Scruples", Scruples is a chic boutique on this chic Beverly Hills shopping street

(3, 2).clue: It's Sanskrit for a word or phrase that's repeated during meditation

(4, 2).clue: 20th c. British philosopher, mathematician & Earl who said knowledge came only from sense

(5, 2).clue: Glenn Close was nominated for a 1980 Tony when she played the wife of this great showman in a musical

(6, 2).clue: This Haitian capital's national museum has the anchor of Columbus' Santa Maria on display

(1, 3).clue: King David II of this country, who spent 18 years in exile & in prison, was Robert the Bruce's son

(2, 3).clue: "Tucker's Last Stand" is yet another Blackford Oakes novel by this eminent conservative

(3, 3).clue: Spanish for "watchmen", it's now a self-appointed champion of law & order

(4, 3).clue: The earliest Greek philosophers are known as "Pre-" this man known for his method

(5, 3).clue: Act 3, Scene 1 of John Osborne's play about this man takes place at the Diet of Worms in 1521

(6, 3).clue: This capital of Trinidad & Tobago was founded in 1595 & named Puerto de Espana

(1, 4).clue: Gandhi lived in this country during the Boer War & served the British as a medical volunteer

(2, 4).clue: "The Fatal Shore" is a nonfiction account of the convict settlement of this country

(4, 4).clue: American philosopher born in Spain in 1863, he's known for his 1905-06 work, "The Life of Reason"

(5, 4).clue: Mark van Doren's play about "The Last Days of" this president opens in William Peterson's house

(6, 4).clue: This Egyptian city was founded in 1859 as a camp for Suez Canal workers

(1, 5).clue: This notorious daughter of a pope married Giovanni Sforza, Lord of Pesaro, in 1493

(2, 5).clue: V.S. Naipaul's 1990 travel book about this country is subtitled "A Million Mutinies Now"

(3, 5).clue: Louisiana Creole word for a small gift given by a shopkeeper to show appreciation

(4, 5).clue: Most of the philosophers of the French Enlightenment contributed to his "Encyclopedie"

(5, 5).clue: In Act II of this Chekhov play, Treplev enters carrying a dead bird

(6, 5).clue: Each October this Texas city has its Cavoilcade, a salute to the petroleum industry

(0, 0).clue: Robert Browning's poem about him contains the line "Rats! They fought the dogs and killed the cats"
